posts.name: mtomczak
posts.cooked:
Working with the ADIS 16470, we found an oddity in the class provided in WPILib (at allwpilib/ADIS16470_IMU.java at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub ).

So if I understand the code correctly, the IMU is probed via the SPI port and gets three acceleration values and three axis turn rate values. However, even though the class writes the axis values to three (private) variables, it only exposes one at a time via the getAngle and getRate methods, and while you can change axis (via setYawAxis`), that operation isn’t “free” (i.e. it toggles to standard SPI then back to auto SPI).

Anyone know why this API is so quirky? Is there a subtlety I’m missing that precludes getting all three rotational axes at the same time?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: You can actually use the getXComplementaryAngle and getYComplementaryAngle  methods to get the other 2 axes. The way gyroscopes work, only the horizontal axes needs all the integration in order to work. The other 2 since they have gravity working for them can actually work differently, which is how the ComplementaryAngle API’s work.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
there are a couple of methods:

and

these methods should give you the pitch and roll of the gyroscope.

posts.name: mtomczak
posts.cooked:
I saw those, but I’m afraid I don’t know what a “complementary angle” is and the functions themselves assume one already knows the definition of that term.

Looking at the source code, it appears those are computed via the accelerometer values, which means they’d be impacted by robot acceleration (and I wouldn’t expect robot acceleration to impact the pitch or roll rate values).

I appreciate the idea though; that’s definitely an approach we can use instead of reading the gyro value (and it has the advantage that we don’t have to do our own integration).

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Internally, the gyro and accelerometer are fused together with a complementary filter. Thats the output given to those functions, and it why its called complementary angle. Agreed a better job could be done for documenting that.

posts.name: Bill Bagshaw
posts.cooked: I have the same problem.  The old 16448 had methods to get each of X, Y, and Z from the three gyros, and I can confirm the the complimentary angle and the filtered angle values do not use the gyros alone.  The PID loop for balancing would work best to have access to the rate.  Since the roborio 2 should be better able to do the computation, I don’t know why each angle isn’t integrated like with the 16448. I also wonder why the library doesn’t have methods to send the raw gyro values.

posts.name: Bill Bagshaw
posts.cooked: That doesn’t explain why the raw gyro values can’t be used on their own and integrated the way they were with the 16448

posts.name: Rob Heslin
posts.cooked:
